article.headline: California 78, UC Riverside 61
article.story: BERKELEY, Calif. (AP) -- With their star player injured and sidelined indefinitely, California is counting on everyone to produce -- even seldom-used players like David Paris. He has never started a game for the Golden Bears, but came up big in the opener. Paris had career-highs of 16 points and eight rebounds in Cal's 78-61 win over UC Riverside in the first round of the Coaches vs. Cancer Classic on Thursday night in the season opener for both teams. "What you're going to find out this year is our posts are better than people think," Paris said. "I don't have anything to prove, but I do feel a little bit more ambitious this year and want to be a leader." Paris, a 6-foot-8 junior, had previously scored seven points three times and had a career scoring average of 1.6 points entering this season. On Thursday, he shot 5-of-7 from the floor, 6-for-6 at the free throw line, passed for four assists, and was a bright spot inside for the Bears with injured sophomore Leon Powe on the sideline in street clothes. Cal struggled to control the boards, but made up for it with a strong perimeter game, aggressive play in the paint and an up-tempo offense. The Bears never trailed and jumped out to a huge lead early. Freshman Eric Vierneisel had 12 points, making all four of his 3-point tries. The Bears, who started three freshmen and a sophomore most of last season, got at least eight points from five other players and hope to have enough scorers to make up for Powe's absence. "We're not going to be a one-guy affair this year," coach Ben Braun said. "It's going to be a different guy every night." Powe had reconstructive surgery on his left knee in September and is expected to miss the entire season. The Pac-10 Freshman of the Year last season and the conference's leading rebounder, he led the Bears with 15.1 points and 9.5 rebounds per game. Larry Cunningham had 18 points to lead UC Riverside, which lost starting center Klaus Schille to his fifth foul with 15:49 left after getting eight points and five rebounds. Vili Morton, the Highlanders' lone returning starter, had 10 points and 14 rebounds. UC Riverside is picked to finish last in the Big West Conference by the coaches and media and has had its share of problems on the road, going 3-13 away from home last season. "We couldn't get in the flow of the game and we didn't get the ball inside enough," Highlanders coach John Masi said. "Instead of staying patient, we burped up some bad shots." Cal will play Friday night against Saint Mary's, a 67-58 winner over Belmont earlier Thursday, with a chance to advance to the tournament semifinals next week at Madison Square Garden in New York. There are three other regions for the 16-team field -- in Syracuse, N.Y.; Birmingham, Ala.; and Memphis, Tenn. UC Riverside will play the early consolation game Friday against Belmont. Cal shot 45 percent in the first half and broke open the game with a 19-4 run highlighted by two 3-pointers from Vierneisel. "My role on this team is to come in and give a scoring threat off the bench," said Vierneisel, who admitted to having a few pregame jitters. "You're going to be nervous, but the only way it's going to go in is if you're confident." The Bears built a 39-17 halftime lead despite getting outrebounded 23-17. This was the Bears' earliest season opener in school history. They began the 2000-01 season on Nov. 13, 2000, against Mississippi State in the Preseason NIT.
